title: How to Stay Safe when a Dog Approaches You

steps.title: Stand still with your arms relaxed at your sides.
steps.content: Stand still with your arms relaxed at your sides. Do not wave your arms or hands around, as this can be seen as aggressive by the dog. Clench your fingers together into loose fists and keep your arms at your sides. Plant your feet hip width apart and stand still. Do not try to touch or pat the dog, as this can be interpreted as aggressive. Never reach out to touch a dog you do not know.

steps.title: Avoid making direct eye contact with the dog.
steps.content: Avoid making direct eye contact with the dog. Do not stare in the dog’s eyes or meet it at eye level. Instead, look at its feet or at your own feet. This will let the dog know that you are not a threat.

steps.title: Move to the side of the dog.
steps.content: Move to the side of the dog. Position your body so you are facing one side of the dog. Do not stand so you are positioned head on with it or behind it, as this can spook it.

steps.title: Speak slowly and calmly around it.
steps.content: Speak slowly and calmly around it. Avoid yelling or shouting around the dog, as this can scare it. Instead, speak in a low, calm voice. You may say “Hello there” or “Nice doggy” to let the dog know you are friendly. If you know the dog’s name, try saying its name a few times calmly and slowly. This will let it know you are not a threat.

steps.title: Allow it to sniff you.
steps.content: Allow it to sniff you. If the dog gets close to you and does not display signs of aggression like growling, crouching, or barking, allow it to sniff your legs or waist. Stay still as it sniffs you. Once it smells you, it may determine you are not a threat and move away from you. If you are not comfortable letting the dog sniff you, move away from the dog safely and slowly so neither of you are in danger.

steps.title: Do not turn your back on the dog.
steps.content: Do not turn your back on the dog. Keep your body facing one side of the dog, as turning your back will put you at risk. Resist the urge to turn and run from the dog as it approaches you, as this could make it more aggressive. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Say “go home” or “down” to the dog.
steps.content: Say “go home” or “down” to the dog. Try communicating with the dog in a low, calm voice. Do not shout or scream at the dog, as this could make it more aggressive. [2] X Research source If you know the dog’s name, trying saying its name a few times so it knows you are a friend.

steps.title: Move away slowly from the dog.
steps.content: Move away slowly from the dog. If you’d like to get away from the dog, do so by slowly backing up. Step back calmly with your body facing one side of the dog. Once you are a few feet away from the dog, turn around slowly and walk away. [3] X Research source Keep the dog in your line of sight as you move away so you are aware of its movements.

steps.title: Keep any dogs or children behind you.
steps.content: Keep any dogs or children behind you. If you have a dog on a leash or small children with you, place them behind you as you back away. This will protect them from the dog without spooking it. [4] X Research source Do not try to pick up the dog or child, as this can be seen as aggressive by the approaching dog.

steps.title: Put an object between you and the dog.
steps.content: Put an object between you and the dog. If you notice the dog is approaching you very aggressively or starts to attack you, grab a nearby object and put it between your body and the dog. Use a purse, a bag, an umbrella, a backpack, or even a bike as a shield between you and the dog. [5] X Research source You can also use a car door as a shield if you are by your car when the dog attacks.

steps.title: Lie face down with your hands over your head.
steps.content: Lie face down with your hands over your head. If you do not have an object nearby, lie down on the ground and place your hands over your head. Curl into a ball and use your hands to protect your neck and head so the dog cannot get to these areas. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Call for help.
steps.content: Call for help. Shout or yell loudly to attract passersby who can help you. You may yell, “Dog attack” or “Help me.” [7] X Research source

steps.title: Get treated for any injuries right away.
steps.content: Get treated for any injuries right away. If you get bitten or sustain other injuries like scratches or scrapes from the dog, go to your nearest emergency center right away. Get your wounds treated and make sure you get the necessary vaccines so you are not at risk of developing an infection or disease. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Report the dog to your local Animal Control.
steps.content: Report the dog to your local Animal Control. You should also report the dog if it attacks you, as you do not want other people to be at risk of getting attacked as well. Describe the breed of the dog and the dog’s name, if you know it. You may also need to discuss where and when you were attacked by the dog. [9] X Research source
